title: 108_hr3286
content:
The "HELP Commission Act" is the short title of this Act, with the purpose outlined in section 2. A commission should be established to review policy decisions, delivery obstacles, methodology, and results of development and humanitarian assistance efforts to address growing despair despite ongoing US efforts. To ensure effective United States development assistance, new approaches and ideas are needed to reach intended recipients beyond purely economic terms. The Commission is established to carry out specific functions. The Helping Enhance the Livelihood of People (HELP) Around the Globe Commission is established to identify past and present objectives of US development assistance, successful cases, ways to expand educational opportunities, and assess infrastructure needs. The HELP Around the Globe Commission aims to assess the effectiveness of US development assistance in lesser developed countries, consider placing conditions on aid, coordinate with other donor countries, ensure safety of aid workers, and compare trade with development assistance. The curr_chunk discusses analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of trade as an alternative to US development assistance, strengthening indigenous NGOs for grassroots development, understanding how political pressures influence aid decisions, involving more people in decision-making, measuring results in least developed countries, and recommending standards for aid. The curr_chunk focuses on recommending standards for "graduating" recipient countries from US development assistance, analyzing the use of aid for achieving foreign policy objectives, evaluating the performance of development assistance programs, including measuring success in democratization efforts, and studying other necessary areas related to US development assistance. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 21 members appointed by the President, Senate majority leader, Senate minority leader, Speaker of the House, and House minority leader. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will also serve as a member. Members appointed under specific paragraphs will serve for the Commission's duration. The Commission consists of 21 members selected for their expertise in foreign assistance. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The President appoints a Chair from private life. The Commission divides into regional subcommittees to manage workload efficiently. The Commission consists of 21 members with expertise in foreign assistance. Each subcommittee elects a Chair, and a majority constitutes a quorum for meetings. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Administrative support is provided by the Administrator of General Services. The Commission on foreign assistance consists of 21 members who serve without pay and are prohibited from receiving additional compensation if they are federal employees. Members are allowed travel expenses for meetings. Administrative support is provided by the Administrator of General Services. The Commission on foreign assistance consists of 21 unpaid members who are prohibited from receiving extra compensation if they are federal employees. Members are allowed travel expenses for meetings, and administrative support is provided by the Administrator of General Services. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation is determined in advance in appropriations Acts. The Chairman of the Commission on foreign assistance has the authority to set the compensation for personnel without following civil service laws, with a maximum pay rate of level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, as outlined in Section 5, has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services to carry out its functions under the Act. The Commission has the authority to adopt rules and regulations for administrative procedures and approve travel for its members to carry out the Act's purposes, including trips to countries receiving US development assistance. Members of Congress may also accompany them on these trips. Upon request, federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission without interruption of their status or privileges. SEC. 6. REPORT OF THE COMMISSION.

The Commission must submit a report with findings and recommendations to the President, Secretary of State, and Congress within 2 years of its appointment. The report may be classified, with a public summary of recommendations. Each member can include individual or dissenting views.

SEC. 7. APPLICABILITY OF OTHER LAWS.

The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission.

SEC. 8. DEFINITION. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. The term "United States development assistance" includes assistance under specific provisions of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and other laws with similar purposes. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for the Commission are authorized to be appropriated, available until the Commission's termination. SEC. 10. TERMINATION. The Commission ends 30 days after submitting its report.
